column1: Uncoupled landing gear
column5:
What if we could take the landing gear off airliners?  Benefits of doing so are on next slide.  The idea is a ground truck/cart that takes the place of on-board gear.  The truck is more like a big driverless platform which matches the aircraft approach underneath and ‘captures’ the aircraft from below as it mirrors the plane’s landing.
Benefits
Less flight weight = less fuel burn
Little to no taxi fuel burn
Less takeoff fuel burn
Smoother landings
Extra space
Longer tire life
Less flight weight = less fuel burn
2 - 5% of MTOW is landing gear.  Eliminate part of this and fuel burn decreases accordingly
Little to no taxi fuel burn
Aircraft APU used during taxi for A/C and power.  Engine start just prior to runway.  
Less takeoff fuel burn
The ground truck with a large rechargeable battery will supply a major part of the thrust on the takeoff run.
Smoother landings
Use of a ground truck for landing allows for upgraded suspension as no weight penalty exists on the ground truck.  
Extra space
More room where the landing gear was could be used for anything or nothing.  Extra fuel if that was desired.  Or extra cargo space.  Or simply for nothing making the MTOW less.
Longer tire life
Tires on the landing truck do not hit the ground stationary.  Thus, no cross-tread splits and wear.
More on the concept
The landing truck would have:
A tracking system to pinpoint its position under the aircraft
An electric drive system to match the aircraft speed
A crosswind steering system to match landing yaw
An upgraded suspension system for a soft landing
A capture system for stability
A communication system with the aircraft

column5:
Reducing power loss in any device is almost always an enabling technology.  Yet, improving the conductivity of copper or reducing the AC Loss in a superconductor presents a significant technical challenge.  Reduction of loss in superconductors requires small diameter wires, twisted, and increased resistivity, and the manufacturing approach often conflicts with higher performance, efficiency, thermal stability, and support at cryogenic temperatures.

Hydrogen aircraft offer ‘free’ cryogenically cooling.  Blended wing body aircraft are enabled by fully superconducting (SC) machines and are the preferred configuration for long range LH2 planes.  Increased number of machine phases or interconnects can reduce the manufacturing complexity of the SC coils, yet more introduce harmonics to increase AC loss and complexity of the electronics and controls, while the AC Loss theory is all based on approximations.
"Wicked-Wild" Idea: Integrate theoretical, computational, and machine learning methods with prior fabrication and machine design approaches of low loss conductors to achieve a no AC loss conductor. Performance and AC loss testing of the wire will be required, along with SEM, cryogenic material property testing, and CFD, and could include many other materials.

sufficiently understand human development and psychology from infancy to adulthood to help prepare them for inhabiting a new environment

In a simple sense AGI is a computational intelligence (AI) that can emulate human reasoning and problem-solving abilities. It can learn, reason, communicate and solve problems in a similar way to humans, and could even supersede human intelligence through self-improvement.
Contemporary machine learning methods utilize sub-symbolic approaches and focus on pattern recognition, classification, function approximation for very specific problems and narrow applications. Usually require massive amounts of data. 
Neuro-symbolic machine intelligence integrates neural networks with symbolic and statistical reasoning methods into a more general framework for implementing more general computational reasoning approaches.

My proposal to the CAS is to study Joined-Wing Structures for their aerodynamic and structural advantages and unconventional options for control surface harmony.
The Joined-Wing arrangement consists of two sets of wings, like a bi-plane, but with significant stagger and sweep such that the arrangement of wings appears like a diamond from above.

A previously developed test-rig concept would allow testing the various configurations in a wind tunnel or scaled demonstrator to collect data.

There is no leap in technology required for evaluating joined-wing structures. Instead, an effort made to test the concepts, collect the data and evaluate the data.

column1: SAPIENS: Keeping expertise alive
column5:
Sound engineering design, arguably, like no other endeavor, requires not just formal education but hands-on work and apprenticeship with experienced “master” engineers. Between the 1940’s and 1960’s, aeronautical engineering went through a tremendous spurt of active aircraft design, resulting in several generations of exceptional aeronautical designers. With cohorts of experienced designers retiring and new engineers having few opportunities for practical experience or “masters” for apprenticeship, industry has suffered an acute decline of expertise in design capabilities and fundamental decision making. This fact has been confirmed repeatedly in conversations with engineers and management in aircraft and automotive industry. In a light but representative example, a world-famous expert and instructor in aeronautical design (Daniel Raymer) related the following: on request by an aircraft manufacturer to observe the design process for a vehicle, he discovered that the engineer in charge was not aware that the tires on a landing gear expand with use and planned for the wheel well to accommodate the new wheel size exactly.  The problem of declining expertise is not limited to aircraft design and is exacerbated by the following factors: •	Traditional designs have reached an equilibrium in many aspects (aircraft as a cylinder with wings). Progressing beyond traditional designs requires a new degree of expertise and inventiveness.  •	The most important step in design, arguably, is the placement of bounds on the system under consideration. Major design mistakes occur when the system under design is too narrow, i.e., when real system complexity is underestimated. Examples abound, from unconsidered effects in human-machine interactions in aircraft design leading to tragic outcomes (e.g., Air France 447) to large-scale catastrophic ecological disasters (Western economists’ attempts to “improve” agriculture in Bali).   With unprecedented global interconnectivity in all aspects of human existence, as well as growing reliance on AI in automated decision-making, aeronautical and other design areas will face enormous, usually unappreciated complexities.   •	As the world grows more complex, paradoxically, education in essential disciplines is declining. In particular, fundamental mathematical reasoning and tools are being taught less, depriving the upcoming designers of the irreplaceable critical faculties and skills.  •	In a related seeming paradox, it has been repeatedly demonstrated thar reliance on AI for decision-making fundamentally weakens the human ability to reason independently. The “use it or lose it” maxim applies. This is a particularly pernicious outcome of over-reliance on AI, because humans quickly lose the capacity for situational awareness and practical evaluation of the outcomes of AI functions.   This is a truly wicked problem: AI gives us information, offers solutions; yet our inevitable overreliance on AI makes us gradually lose the ability to reason and even evaluate what AI does for us.   Proposed solution space: Develop a multimodal AI Design Assistant that would assist a human designer throughout all stages of design, from requirement elicitation to formulating the design problem in required complexity to formulating representations amenable to solution and analysis of system-wide consequences, without negative impact on human cognitive capabilities.  NASA has tremendous expertise and data in complex systems design. We should work on developing AI tools that help create new designs that work in our world of ever growing, unprecedented complexity, rather than undermine our awareness and ability to function competently. Such tools would be of use not just to NASA or just in aeronautical engineering, but to all educational institutions and all areas that involve decision-making. 
The entire DOD, as well as aircraft manufacturers, are well aware of this problem. In a specific example, a Boeing colleague revealed in a recent conversation that the declining expertise is so pronounced that Boeing is attempting to collect all possible previous design examples to teach them to the new engineers. However, parsing through thousands of examples to extract appropriate information is turning out to be very difficult. It is simply not clear on what to focus and what information to choose. The main barrier would be the availability of data. For instance, it is not clear that aircraft manufacturers would be eager to share their data that involve not just successes but failures, which is essential for developing appropriate design assistants. However, this risk/barrier can be mitigated as follows. NASA does have its own data, which can be use for the development of the basic tools. Once the fundamental methodology and tools are in place, external organizations can use them to train using their own data.
The problem is acute right now and may blow up unpredictably, especially with proposed designs for climate change. 
The problem can come to a head at any instant. For example, given the critical climate developments, it will be increasingly easy to attempt large-scale engineering solutions, such as geoengineering, with potentially disastrous unintended consequences. We have many examples of ecological disasters due to attempts to manage systems without full understanding of system boundaries and effects (e.g., the Bali example). Large-scale geoengineering attempts can potentially have disastrous and irreversible consequences. Some attempts have been made already (Mexico), albeit on a small scale. The need to reverse the loss of expertise and sound decision-making is critical.
Please see the answer to Question 2. 
Large language models (underlying technology, not just the question-and-answer aspect), multidisciplinary and multiobjective analysis and design optimization, mathematical modeling, systems analysis, human-machine interaction, cognitive science, software engineering. 
Aeronautic engineering is in major need of a prompt solution to declining expertise (please see Items 2 and 3) and would be an immediate beneficiary of a solution.

The effects of the loss of expertise in engineering design range from the obvious, such as aircraft crashes, to globe-wide effects, such as potential geoengineering solutions without a sound understanding of the consequences, and to various social consequences.

column5:
What if NASA Aeronautics could enable astonishing improvements in our ability to predict the intensity and tracks of tropical storms? Atlantic hurricanes are produced by dynamic processes that start on the other side of the ocean, in air masses that leave the continent of Africa. Important details of these processes are invisible to space-based remote sensing instruments. In-situ measurements are the only way we can understand and follow the processes that may or may not produce a tropical cyclone.  There is a strong need for continuous in-situ surveillance of these air masses as they traverse the Atlantic to follow their development and predict where, when, and how they will impact us.
NASA is deeply involved in efforts to address this problem and is a valued partner of NOAA, the EPA, and the academic institutions and commercial companies that are focused on this area.   Solutions must meet strict science requirements while also being practical in terms of cost, operational complexity, and environmental sustainability.  Solutions will need to integrate seamlessly into existing data capture and analysis workflows and be compatible with international laws and regulations regarding use of the skies and sea.  
This problem is an annual, recurring issue that impacted 792 million people in 2019, according to a Rand Corporation study.  Every hurricane season brings risk, along with opportunities to advance our understanding and improve our responses.  
Continuously. Officially, hurricane season runs from June through November, with storms at their most intense and numerous from August into October.  Due to climate change, the severity of these storms and their impacts will continue to increase substantially. 
In 2005, I was part of a small team tasked with determining whether HALE (High Altitude Long Endurance) aircraft of that time were a potential solution to this problem.  They were not.  There have been substantial advances in many relevant technologies since that time.  In 2022, the Zephyr 8 solar-powered, high altitude aircraft stayed aloft for 64 days, at an altitude of 60,000 feet, traversing 35,000 miles. From 2011 to 2021, Google’s Loon project developed and matured a wide range of technologies that made managing an actively controlled fleet of high altitude balloons a reality.  Today, there are thousands of autonomous drones operating routinely in the world’s oceans, supporting all kinds of science.  These include SailDrones that range in size from 14-72 feet and displace up to 14 tons. SpaceX has also demonstrated to utility of autonomous ocean barges to support flight operations at sea. 
Solutions in this space will take the form of aerial platforms that can carry and support the scientific instruments required to make the needed in-situ atmospheric measurements. They must meet requirements for both spatial and temporal measurement intervals to establish effectively continuous surveillance of the evolution of these air masses.  Taking these measurements for weeks at a time, over the open ocean, may require launching or recovering the aerial platforms from seagoing vessels.  Autonomous systems and autonomous operations may be critical to clearing cost and sustainability barriers.  New commercial aerial platforms coming to market may open new paths to meeting these needs, but if they fall short there are opportunities for creative ideas that leverage other new technologies to close gaps and enable new step-changes in capability.
These in-situ measurements must be made from platforms flying in the air they need to measure.

Why is this a problem? 
This is a subset of a broader set of problems associated with the introduction of new technology and it’s impact on patient health. This scenario is different from conventional usage of air transportation that traditionally involves significant human in the loop interactions. Rather, to the extent that autonomous and automated systems become an aspect of health care, a new set of medical ethics concerns arise. Patient monitoring is necessary during medical transport. If this involves an autonomous or automated transportation system, then That patient information resides with in that autonomous or automated system and it needs to be handled appropriately. Timely delivery of supplies and services by whatever means is a core foundation of health care. If an autonomous or automated system fails in its designated function, that failure just impacts individual health care and an understanding of responsibility or liability is needed_. Broadly speaking, issues involved are: 
Privacy 
Local regulations, laws 
Decision making 
Medical transport 
Liability 
Maximizing patient care 
What capabilities may be needed to address the problem? 
There are two aspects of this problem. The first is technical regarding the capability of an autonomous or automated system the carry out its function in an optimized fashion minimizing impact to patient health. The second is the framework of legal and societal restrictions that impose upon the autonomous or automated system a layer of functionality that, for example, ensures confidentiality of patient information or appropriate response in emergency condition. 
What trends might enable problem exploration and solution? 
One trend is that health care on a local level is becoming increasingly more distributed and advanced. The complexity of health care provided by, for example, emergency air evacuation services has increased over the years. The overall trend is that more can be done locally rather than in a centralized hospital setting. A second trend is changes in the air transportation system is envisioned over time to allow new forms of both personal air transport_ as well as also delivery of supply and materials. A third trend is the advancement of artificial intelligence and data handling systems that may be able to not only allow new types of vehicle operations, but also an ability to handle information in a more complex and situationally appropriate manner. 
Reach - How many people, communities are going to be impacted or are impacted by the problem?. 
The overall impact varies depending on the type of transport. Related to emergency transport and care, the population may be limited and more concentrated in rural areas. However other forms of medical transport are much more common. For example, professional transport a patient from one health care facility to another is a relatively common occurrence within parameters dictated by legal and health insurance regulations. Further, if air transportation and medical supplies using, for example, autonomous or automated drones becomes a common occurrence, then the impact on the overall health care system on the performance of these technologies can be significant and broad based. 
Impact - What is the scale of the impact? (high, medium, low) 
Score: High (depending on the application) 
Confidence - How confident are we in the impact and reach determinations? 
Score: _Medium 
This assessment depends upon the development and implementation of technologies still in their formation stage and have not established a economic foothold in the market.

The technical aspects of this problem are within NASA’s domain and are specific application in the healthcare field of evolving air transportation autonomous and automated systems. The legal and societal aspects of this transformation that might be addressed by technological advances, but in general are more dependent on economic factors in the health care system beyond NASA’s purview.

column1: How might the entire aviation experience be restructured to reduce its risk as a vector of pathogen transmission? (reducing unnecessary contact, etc.)
column5:
Why is this a problem? 
The drive to reduce human interaction in aviation has at least 2 influencing factors: The attempt to safeguard public health from the spread of contagions; and an economic drive towards automation to decrease staffing and expense associated with airline and the airport employees. However, this can lead to the depersonalization of air travel and, depending on the efficiency of the automation, potential inefficiencies in handling customer complaints/problems as well as removing a public face representing and individual airline company. 
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7134995/ 
https://scholarship.law.wm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1223&context=wmblr 
If the aviation industry is a major vector for pathogen transmission, it will continue to generate global pandemics as strict border control will be more porous than otherwise. 
What capabilities may be needed to address the problem?
At the very least, the interactions of automated system should be at least as efficient as human based customer service. This implies improved artificial intelligence be implemented so that either unexpected events can be addressed or quickly re-routed to human staffing.
Additional interfaces need to be designed to be pathogen resistant in case cleaning is less effective or skipped.
Standard, practiced changes to routing and operations if pathogens are detected or a higher risk of transmission.
Additional changes to cabin design to mitigate risk.
Airport redesign to reduce transmission while waiting in line, etc.
Deployable pathogen detection inside airports and airplanes (i.e.?next gen temperature guns, mid-flight pathogen testing).
Personal Pods for breathing to keep passengers safe from other passengers Hyundai’s AV pod concepts promise better living through modularity - CNET 
What trends might enable problem exploration and solutioning?  
(Worker to Passenger vectors) Automated check-in and self-serve kiosks have already become a standard aspect of flight service. This drive to minimize staffing and increase automation in customer service is already happening across multiple industries. Increasing automation and autonomous systems may result in airports in which the process is fully automated and one does not have to interact with a member of the airline or airport staff in order to board the plane. 
(Passenger to Passenger) Use of masks and availability of sanitizing wipes or fluids, post COVID, will set cultural norms to reduce P2P transmission.  
(Passenger to Worker) The current staffing shortages and union fights for airline staff may drive additional investments in safety technology to keep pilots and flight attendants healthy and safe.  
Personal transportation pods (land-based) may offset the need for air transport. Personal Rapid Transit: Driverless Pods of the (Retro) Future | by Alex Beyman | DataDrivenInvestor  
Remote work may reduce the need for air transport regardless. 
Reach - How many people, communities are going to be impacted or are impacted by the problem? 
Score: 6 (1 Billion) 
4.5 B passengers fly per year globally. The percentage of people get sick from 1st or 2nd order connection to flying is really hard to find. There is moderate consensus around the 2-row rule on commercial crafts at a 13% infectivity rate for COVID, but not generally for all pathogens. Our research confirms that more research is needed. At a minimum we believe the population is 100M, but could be 1B. 
The reach of this trend will be extensive and affecting two sets of communities: 
The whole of the traveling public 
Airport/airline personnel who at greater risk of becoming ill by virtue of their exposure 
Facts regarding population sizes: 
4.5 Billion passengers fly globally annually 
502 mi avg flight or ~1-2hrs 
133 minutes on average in the airport from arrival to boarding. 
One day in 2022, 1/3 of United Airlines staff at Newark were out sick. 3000 total across United on that day. 
There are few studies around how many passengers get sick from travel and they have widely differing results. In “What proportion of international travelers acquire a travel-related illness? A review of the literature”, a 2018 paper the actual quote shows the limitations and variability of attempting to bracket this number: - “All studies collected data through either extraction from the medical record, weekly diaries, or pre- and post-travel questionnaires. Data collection timeframes varied by study. Between 6–87% of travelers became ill across all studies. Four studies provided the best estimate: between 43–79% of travelers who frequently visited developing nations (e.g.?India, Tanzania, and Kenya) became ill” https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5825178/ 
Impact - What is the scale of the impact?
Score: 2.5 - 2.5 (2-3)
Given the impact of most pathogens is not life threatening, but the impact to the economy, plus the percentage of life threatening or deadly outcomes is nontrivial. 
Confidence - How confident are we in the impact and reach determinations? 
2.5 (2-3) The impact of most pathogens is not life threatening, but the impact to the economy, plus the percentage of life threatening or deadly outcomes is also nontrivial. 
Wickedness? CAS-worthy?
This may be a technological progression that will first be implemented in the range of other industries before it reaches aviation. This may not be CAS-worthy problem because the market is already addressing automation (for costs).
But from the pathogen side and from the in-the-tube spread, automation doesn’t account for all interactions and may not even shield people from the most common mechanisms of pathogen transmission (because we don’t know what they are). From that perspective, CAS may have an valid entry point. There may be aircraft design and technology investments specific to the aircraft that may be worthwhile IF the pathogen transmissions is validated as a big problem. (See Capabilities list).

Why is this a problem? 
Large portions of the US population, particularly those with the greatest health challenges, do not participate in clinical research studies and thus do not benefit from those discoveries. Low accrual issues overall are the cause of 55% of terminated clinical trials. This lack of representation compromises generalizability, hinders innovation, impacts trust in the medical system, and compounds health disparities of communities without access. 
What capabilities may be needed to address the problem? 
Often, clinical trials are centered around academic or research institutions limiting participation by a broader sampling of the population. Capabilities to address this problem revolve around improving the ability for patients to participate, or, effectively, bringing the clinical trial to the patients. 
For example, travel impacts out-of-pocket costs to patients, typically driving remote patients out of studies. Distance as a driver of disparity has been specifically established as a cause of lack participation by rural communities. 
Thus, one capability to improve participation would be to increase the accessibility to transportation in rural communities. 
Further, telemedicine and virtual or localized trial treatments may broaden the geographic diversity. 
While some aspects of this transformation are more related to overall trends in health care technology, the ability to provide well equipped mobile airborne laboratories could impact the ability to increase participation in clinical trials in rural communities. 
Beyond issues related to location, there is in general a lack of participation by racial and ethnic minority populations for a variety of socio-economic reasons. Specific outreach may be required to these populations, so investment in greater capabilities in community coordination.

A broadening of capabilities in aviation to allow more democratized transportation and the ability to bring more comprehensive health care capabilities, including clinical trial participation, no I don’t to remote regions; 
Increasing level of capabilities due to technical advances allowing more localized and effective health care.

Reach - How many people, communities are going to be impacted or are impacted by the problem? 
Very High - 1 Billion 
US Participation was 28% of the total representation in global Clinical trials in 2015. The problem in the US is also then a global representation problem. With personalized genetic mods, medicine, this will become worse. With Climate change, disease and medical impacts will also worsen in the most distressed areas and populations (not currently studied). Specific rural communities are impacted by this problem already within the US. For example, distance as a driver of disparity has been specifically established for Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander populations who are more likely to live far away from research centers. 
Academic centers conduct 55% of the NIH extramural research and operate 98% of the cancer centers. Participation in these activities is biased by the proximity to these centers. However, more broadly, effective clinical trials as a method for improved treatment and drug development has an impact on the population as a whole. Limiting the effectiveness of these trials because of a lack of participation by significant population subgroups narrows the trial’s impact and reduces benefits to society beyond the immediate drug and research. 
Impact - What is the scale of the impact? 
Score: 4 
More disease due to climate change. Growing disparity in access and research participation. More hospital consolidation leads to more illness in rural areas, where people are less likely to participate in studies to begin with. 
Confidence - How confident are we in the impact and reach determinations? 
Score: 3.5 
The limitations in broad participation in clinical studies can be referenced from multiple sources. We are confident in the reach of this problem. But we can only estimate the first order impact of the problem, given its complexity and the nature of the follow-on effects. 
Effort – what is the effort/scale needed to address? Wickedness? CAS-ARMD/NASA aligned? 
The aspect of participation in clinical trials is a subset of broader challenges related to access to healthcare in rural regions and amongst racial and ethnic minorities. 
While technical improvements may reduce the pain of this problem, it can be solved with current technologies and appropriate coordination and incentives. Technology can be only one path to a solution.

column1: How might aviation mitigate growth of drug resistant bacteria due to heavy metal manufacturing and usage? (advanced manufacturing, airport safety protocols, and aircraft design)
column5:
Sibling Question: 
How will aviation mitigate growth of drug resistant bacteria due to increased usage of antimicrobials in response to COVID-19? (airport safety protocols, and aircraft design) 
Why is this a problem?
Drug resistant bacteria is propagated by the use of heavy metals (lead, mercury, and silver) because of mining and transportation usage. Bacteria have evolved to resist the presence of these heavy metals, producing traits that also shield them from antibiotics. 
Normally heavy metals are lethal to bacteria because of the free emission of ions that disrupt cell functions. 
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global health and development threat. It requires urgent multisectoral action in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). 
WHO has declared that AMR is one of the top 10 global public health threats facing humanity. 
Misuse and overuse of antimicrobials are the main drivers in the development of drug-resistant pathogens. 
Lack of clean water and sanitation and inadequate infection prevention and control promotes the spread of microbes, some of which can be resistant to antimicrobial treatment. 
The cost of AMR to the economy is significant. In addition to death and disability, prolonged illness results in longer hospital stays, the need for more expensive medicines and financial challenges for those impacted. 
Without effective antimicrobials, the success of modern medicine in treating infections, including during major surgery and cancer chemotherapy, would be at increased risk. 
“The site contained a strain of bacteria resistant to 70 percent of antibiotics tested against it.” heavy metal toxicity. Ultrasound was needed for the diagnosis of obstetric and intra-abdominal conditions. Further, screening for a ride range of cancers needs to be increased notably."

column1: Re-Skilling & Training the Future Aviation Mechanics Workforce
column5:
With the introduction of novel automation technologies, energy storage equipment, and advanced power plants there will be a need to prime the aviation training pipeline so that there are enough Aviation Maintenance Technicians (AMT) and certified Airframe and Powerplant (A&P) mechanics available to service the novel aircraft of the future. 
New curriculum programs will be needed to train mechanics how to troubleshoot, diagnose, and repair aircraft that use liquid hydrogen fuel and electric batteries. Type qualifications for hydrogen aircraft would likely require training for working with cryogenics, management of explosive fuels, and new compressor designs. Likewise mechanics obtaining a type qualification for electric aircraft (and eVTOLs) will need to taught the best practices for maintaining electric aircraft engines, their high-voltage batteries, and their coolant systems.
Training schools and universities that routinely graduate certified AMTs and A&Ps will likely adapt to the changing maintenance landscape organically. Striving to produce the most competitive mechanics, these organizations will likely lead the charge in the race to develop curriculums that prepare graduates to work with these new aircraft. However, many maintenance companies that contract out labor to airlines and flight service centers will likely lag behind owing to the fact that the bulk of their existing business is to service conventional aircraft. However, if the AAM market gains dominance, and hydrogen and electric aircraft begin to compete for A&Ps, then the in-service workforce will need to seek out supplemental training programs that will teach them how to work on these new aircraft. 
It is foreseeable that a large, well distributed, network of A&Ps will be required to maintain the growing airline and AAM fleets of the future. These mechanics will be essential to ensure that both airline and AAM operations are efficient, timely, and safe. This may be especially true at smaller regional airports and vertistops where there could be little to no supporting infrastructure and where damaged/inoperable aircraft would critically disrupt or halt flight operations until the aircraft is serviced.

column1: Securing the Future Aviation Workforce
column5:
Background – Workforce in Aviation
The Geneva-based Air Transport Action Group (ATAG) estimates that the aviation industry is supported by roughly 87.7 million workers globally [1]. 
11.3m directly support the industry: airport ops, airlines, manufacturing, and navigation (i.e., ATC). 
18.1m indirectly support aviation: fuel, logistics, supply chains, retail, customer support, IT.
13.5m are induced by the industry: banks, restaurants, ancillary consumer goods focused on aviation.
44.8m are classified as “aviation-enabled tourism”: hotels, resorts, charters, etc.
There is currently a pilot shortage that is a result of both COVID-19 and a wave of early and mandatory senior pilot retirements [2]. At Delta, 20% of its staff took buyout packages or early retirement offered in response to COVID-19 [5]. One of the largest flight instruction companies, CAE, has estimated that more than 264,000 new pilots will be needed over the next 10 years. Likewise, Boeing estimates that 612,000 new pilots, 626,000 maintenance technicians, and 886,000 crew members will be needed to support the aviation industry over the next 20 years [3]. Further more, some estimates state that the AAM industry will demand of approximately 60,000 pilots by the year 2028 [4].
The industry is working to address these staffing shortages but with limited success. Some estimates suggest that the sector will be short 80,000 pilots by 2032 [6]. If AAM does develop into a competitive employer of pilots, there is no known method to secure the number of pilots required using today’s training pipeline.
Some companies within the aviation industry are looking to reduce their staffing requirements by adopting to policies such as Single Pilot Operations (SPO) in combination with heightened levels of automation. Many AAM startups hope to one day offer completely autonomous air travel to their customers, eliminating the need for a human pilot entirely. 
The complete impacts on the future of the global and aviation workforces remain difficult to define. Several of the key elements that will drive the workforce of the future are largely out of government / corporate control. Changes in public sentiment towards work, and its role within their lives, are difficult to forecast or control. 
However, there are elements where we could see considerable impacts arise naturally…
Automation: Advances in autonomous autopilots could obviate the need for pilots in commercial aircraft [1]. Such advances could reduce the needed number of pilots an airline would need to employ. Further more, it has been speculated that automation within aviation maintenance could provide operational performance benefits in addition to labor substitution [2]. This shift could potentially shutter long-standing training schools/companies who depend on the high volume of pilots / maintenance students moving into the industry. 
AI: Smarter software products that feature advanced AI could significantly reduce the amount of time and effort that is needed to complete many computer-based tasks that are currently accomplished by humans [3]. Such examples could include: fleet personnel management, flight routing and dispatching, aircraft modeling and design, simulation and validation, etc.
AAM: Speculations regarding the size of AAM fleets and their pilot demands vary. Some organizations estimate that as many as 60,000 AAM pilots could be needed by 2028 [4]. This surge in demand could severely restrict how many pilots large airlines could recruit, leading to increased scheduling delays, cancelations, and lost revenues. 
How might the aviation industry establish competitive recruitment programs, college and flight training scholarships, and engagement efforts within high schools and universities to secure the future of the aviation industry and its workforce?
Will AAM pilots be represented by a pilots union?
How competitive will AAM pilot compensation programs be? Will airlines be able to compete for talent and expertise using their in-service compensation model?
How will advanced AI impact the staffing requirements of Airlines’ dispatch departments?
How will autonomous flight impact the staffing requirements of ATC centers?
How will autonomous flight impact the roles and responsibilities of human pilots in the cockpit? Will the need for human pilots be eliminated? 
What new industries will need to be established to support AAM operations? 
How will a permanent shift of employees into remote work postures impact the aviation industry?
What skill and expertise gaps exist within the design and engineering domains of aviation today? Will those gaps be exacerbated or solved by an increasingly specialized workforce?
Will companies devote time and resources to help reskill the workforce they have? Or will companies abandon their current employees and hire new, already trained, workers who possess the skills and knowledge that are needed to advance the company’s agenda?

column1: Advancing Water Security
column5:
Background – How water is used in Aviation
The earth has 1.3 BsqKM of water. 97% is salt water, 3% is freshwater. However, only 1.2% of all freshwater is available for use. The remainder is either stored as ice, in deep aquifers, or the atmosphere [1,2].  Of all water used globally, the agriculture sector is the largest single user (68%). The industrial sector, including most of the aviation industry, uses about 12%.
The amount of water that is used by the aviation industry varies widely and is domain specific. For instance, the manufacturing side of the aviation industry has a different water use footprint than the airport operations side. 
Historically, Airbus has reported that they use 1 Bgal of water per year [3]. This is approximately equal to the daily water demands of New York City or Chicago. Where as a single airport’s water footprint can range from  9 – 43 liters per passenger (table 2) [4].
A key step to achieving Zero Impact Aviation will be to establish Airport Water Resource Management Plans that have ambitious water efficiency goals that minimize the amount of water that is consumed system wide. These plans [5,6]
Background – Water Use in Aviation
Of all water used globally, the agriculture sector is the largest single user (68%) of fresh water [1]. They heavily rely on two classifications of water:
Green Water -  Water that is found in top-soil; replenished by natural rainfall.
Blue Water – Water that is manually irrigated; drawn from waterways and underground aquifers.
Demand for blue water irrigation is the largest drain on aquifers across the globe as farms struggle to provide their crops with enough water. Areas of the planet that have historically been able to rely on green water (i.e., reliable rainfall) will need to rely even more heavily on the use of irrigation. As a result, many of the worlds most vital aquifers are being depleted at unsustainable rates that are leading to levels of water scarcity that have a direct impact on the quantify of food that can be cultivated each year [2]. 
The aviation industry is continuing to invest in SAFs and bio-fuels. By doing so, they are also increasing the demand for blue water irrigation that is needed to grow the crops that will be converted into fuels. The aviation industry’s demand for biofuels will hasten the depletion of key aquifers that are essential for food production.
As the aviation industry transitions away from jet fuel to alternative energy sources, it will need to understand and reconcile with the impact its energy needs have on water availability. 
Background – Planetary Boundaries (Freshwater)
In 2009, the Stockholm Resilience Centre worked with a group of renowned scientists to identify and quantify the processes that stabilize and provide resilience to our planet. The scientists proposed nine quantitative planetary boundaries (shown at the right). Operating within these boundaries enables humanity to continue to thrive. Crossing these boundaries can increase the risk of generating large-scale abrupt of irreversible environmental changes. [2]
In 2022, scientists reassessed how they were quantifying the freshwater boundary to include green water. Green water links the freshwater boundary to other boundaries like land-system change, biodiversity, and climate change. 
Green water is the main source of water to produce “food, feed, fiber, timber, and bioenergy.” [4]. Scarcity of green water, while often overlooked in research, will impact the ability to scale up green energy alternatives like SAFs or hydrogen without impacting food security.  
When powered by bio-fuels (i.e., SAFs), aircraft are the most water intensive form transportation. One study estimated that bio-fuel powered aircraft demand 65 – 136 liters of water, per passenger, per kilometer traveled. In some cases, flying with biofuels has four times the water footprint of bio-fuel powered passenger vehicles [5]. This finding implies that switching to bio-fuels to power the aviation industry could have an outsized impact on the demand of water compared to alternative forms of transport. 
However, even non-biofuel alternatives, such as hydrogen have a large water footprint. Water UK’s Net Zero 2030 Roadmap estimates that if hydrogen emerges as an alternate fuel, than water demand will increase by 15 – 20%. [9] Some estimates suggest that global hydrogen industry’s demand for fresh water will grow from 1.5 bcm to 25 bcm by 2050 [2]. 1 bcm = 1 billion cubic meters (i.e., 264.2 billion gallons). [10] 25 bcm of water is approximately the municipal water need of 62 million people (Pop. of California and Florida combined).
Availability of fresh water varies across the world. RO desalination appears to provide the most economic path towards providing the feedstock for this process. However, RO and its alternative, thermal distillation, will place an increased demand on the power grid, impose considerable land use concerns, and have waste byproducts (e.g., brine) that require treatment and disposal. [8]
Projected Impacts
Water shortages leading to water scarcity - the UN estimates that by 2030, half the population will live in high water stressed areas. [6] 
Food scarcity due to decreased agricultural capacity – A 2012 ICA report judged that the depletion of groundwater supplies in some agricultural areas—owing to poor management—will pose a risk to both national and global food markets in the near-term [4]
Economic decline –Production of water-intensive goods like water, food, and clothing could be limited. Moreover, agriculture and industry will be limited due to a lack of freshwater access. [7]
Inadequate sanitation, leading to deadly diarrheal diseases and water-borne illnesses [2]
Increased global migration and displacement – some 700 million people could be displaced by intense water scarcity by 2030 [5]
Increased global conflict, including social disruption, political instability, and water being used as leverage. Latin America is already seeing these disputes and this unrest first-hand. [4] [9]
Increased threat of riots and other turmoil – during Cape Town’s countdown to Day Zero, they were warned that the water crisis presented a “threat to social order,” and could lead to civil strife and increased crime [8]
Destruction of habitats and loss of biodiversity
Rationale 
As the aviation industry transitions to alternative fuels, significant consideration must be given to the impact that will have on water availability. Although this is a looming problem, there is little focus on addressing this challenge now as most of the effort is focused on addressing the alligator closest to the boat, carbon emissions. 
CAS has the ability to help the aviation industry get ahead of this problem by exploring mitigation paths, alternative SAF options that utilize minimal water, researching the potential impact of the hydrogen economy. Further exploration is also needed on the impact of increased domestic mining on water availability and water quality. 
This is a tremendously wicked problem due, in part, to its high level of uncertainty. It is unclear to what extent aviation emissions play a role in water pollution. Nor is it clear how to properly balance the food-energy-water nexus in service of both our climate change goals and our need to ensure food and water systems remain secure.
The importance of water availability cannot be overstated. Water is our lifeblood. Still, as critical as this topic is, its connection to the aviation sector is tenuous. Several team members ranked it in lower in terms of value because they viewed it as not being a core area for NASA or they viewed water availability as being a fairly minimal area of concern for aviation at this time.

column1: Rethinking Aviation's Approach to Waste
column5:
Background
“Green” aviation is an ambitious vision but can be messy in execution. Often, decisions made in the name of sustainable aviation are mired with unintended consequences and unfortunate trade-offs. 
For example, airlines toss 9,000 tons of plastic annually. Reducing the plastic used in catering operations would seem like an easy win, but it’s not that simple. Plastic has its advantages too. Plastic is lightweight, which translates to a reduction in carbon emissions as compared to glass and cutlery. Moreover, use of plastic in catering is more sanitary, reducing the spread of infectious disease. [1]
Similarly, shifts to electric aviation will reduce emissions significantly, but result in an “e-waste timebomb.” [2] Many of the current processes for recycling the necessary batteries are energy intensive and not designed for the scale that will be required. 
This problem is shared by other “green” energy resources like solar panels and wind turbines, which will be necessary to power the electrification of aviation. Wind turbines and aircraft decommissioning, in particular, face very comparable problems. Well-intentioned policies to increase energy efficiency, result in wind turbines being sent to landfills long before their expected lifecycle has ended. [5] Similarly, many planes are likely to be decommissioned at a faster rate than usual in order to shift to newer designs that will curtail emissions. Each generation of aircraft is typically 15-20% more fuel-efficient than the one it replaces. It is likely that older aircraft will be retired earlier in order to gain these fuel efficiencies and each net-zero pledges. [5], [6], [7] 
Much like wind turbines, the composite materials used in newer, more fuel-efficient aircraft designs are difficult to recycle. Both composite aircraft and wind turbines are difficult to recycle effectively and cheaply, meaning that wind turbine blades often end up sitting in landfills or buried in landfills. Unless significant effort is made to advance the processes and management plans for these types of materials, the same may be the case for composite aircraft when they reach end of life. [8] At present, 85% – 93% of aircraft components are recyclable, but those numbers may change as composite aircraft reach end-of-life. [10] [11]
Challenges
Many of the processes for recycling these materials are still in their infancy. Research into recycling composite materials and photovoltaics, for instance, has been had some early success, but additional work is needed to ready these processes for full-scale implementation.[1] [12] 
The recycling technology itself can sometimes be environmentally damaging, relying on harsh chemicals and energy intensive processes such as the case with battery recycling. [6] [11]
Efforts to reduce waste can be inefficient and ineffective. Compostable cutlery is only beneficial insofar as the cutlery actually gets composted. In many cases, however, there are rarely any clearly defined process or standards to ensure materials are diverted from landfills into recycling plants or compost centers. Waste management tools and systems are needed to ensure that components are disposed of properly. [2] [3]
Meeting the climate change challenge necessitates rapid innovation to continually build better batteries, aircraft, wind turbines, and solar panels. This fluctuation can be a deterrent to investing in end-of-life processing. For example, a company may be hesitant to invest in recycling Li-ion batteries while the future of the market is still relatively unstable. If Li air or hydrogen fuel cells takes off instead, the demand for Li-ion could crash. Even Li-ion batteries themselves often vary greatly with regards to composition, which can make recycling challenging. [11] 
The financial incentives to invest in recycling certain “green” materials like solar panels are low. Many of the materials, like glass, are low-value and the long life-span of the panels reduces the ROI. It costs $20 - $30 to recycle one solar panel, but sending the same panel to the landfill costs only $1 - $2. [4] Even in the case of battery recycling where many of the components are high-value, recycling plants are often costly to build and require sophisticated equipment to treat the harmful emissions that are a byproduct of the smelting process. [11]
Projected Impacts – Going to Waste
The waste generated by the aviation industry is significant. Left unmanaged, much of this waste will end up in landfills where, in the best case, it simply goes to waste. In the worst case, however, this material has the potential to be harmful to our environment and to our health. 

A healthy aviation ecosystem will require the ability to scale up recycling and end-of-life processing capacity. Demand for many of these resources is exceptionally high and they are increasingly difficult to come by due to geopolitical issues and supply chain concerns. Building a robust and circular aviation economy aimed at reducing waste across its value stream will be critical to ensuring continued growth and the ability to meet net-zero goals. 

There is tremendous projected growth in aviation waste in the coming years due to several factors, including efforts to meet net-zero emissions, which will result in an influx of new energy infrastructure, more fuel-efficient aircraft, and shifts to alternative energy sources. Covid-19 is an additional factor of consideration. Airlines are expected to increase the retirement rate of aircraft by 10 – 15% due to the pandemic. [4] Qantas and other airlines have delayed milestone goals to reduce single use plastics because of the sanitation benefits provided by them. [1] [3]

Industry is anticipating and investing in this growth, as evidenced by investment in battery recycling labs like Redwood and Battery Resourcers and by DOE’s investment in the ReCell lab. Moreover, collaboration between North American Aerospace Industries (NAAI), Aries Aerospace, and the Aircraft Interior Recycling Association are pushing toward 100% recyclable aircraft. [5] [6] This shift in thinking about recyclability is evidenced even in newer start-ups like Boom supersonic, who are incorporating recyclability into their initial design process [7]. Aerospace scrap is the fastest-growing source of carbon fiber in terms of value. [8]
Projected Impacts – Environment and Human Health
Waste from the aviation lifecycle ends up in landfills, aircraft boneyards, or storage facilities. The use of these spaces to accommodate this waste often means damaging or reducing natural habitats for wildlife. [3]
With regard to plastic waste, only 9% of aviation’s single use plastic waste is recycled, meaning that a huge percentage of this waste ends up in landfills or in the ocean. Landfilling has been shown to cause the accumulation of plastics in both terrestrial and marine ecosystems. [7] This plastic leakage can impact everything from crop yield to the increased spread of pathogens through the “plastisphere”. [8], [9], [10]
Microplastics, a result of mismanaged plastic waste being worn down into smaller pieces, have infiltrated the ocean, the rain, and even the human body. Just this spring, scientists found microplastics in donor blood and inside the lungs of two surgical patients. Scientists are still researching whether these microplastics are harmful to human health. [4] 
Waste can be toxic or hazardous to human health. In the case of solar panels, for instance, toxic metals like lead, chromium, and cadmium can be harmful to humans are likely to leak from electronic waste dumps into drinking water supplies. [1]
Further, when not disposed of properly, lithium-ion batteries pose a safety risk. These batteries are composed of volatile compounds, capable of sparking spontaneously. [6]
The reuse and recycling of many of these materials also reduces environmental degradation from mining and the geopolitical and human rights issues associated with sourcing many of these materials. As shown in the chart on the bottom left, China has significant control over the production of many of these materials, which the Biden administration has acknowledged means that we “risked losing our edge as a nation.” [11]
Rationale
CAS has the potential to rethink aviation’s approach to “waste.” Helping to shift the thinking around these waste products so that they are seen as valuable resources. This is a growing problem that has the potential to turn into a near-term solution to help bolster aviation’s supply chain and enable the sector to continue growing. Moreover, aviation waste has the potential to open new markets and lines of revenue for manufacturers and airlines, adding additional resilience during unexpected downturns like the pandemic. This is an urgent problem/opportunity area. Although there is some energy focused on this topic area, many of the ongoing efforts are focused on our current understanding of the aviation lifecycle, including current compositions of EV batteries (Li-ion) and existing aircraft. Pursuing this topic area would mean broadening the focus beyond this current state to envision end-of-life for the aviation well into the future. It would also open the aperture to include energy infrastructure waste.   
Recommended Next Steps and Critical Questions
What do we propose as a next step?  Broad problem formulation and opportunity area discovery using a synthesis is recommended for exploring waste management for the future aviation lifecycle. This topic area would benefit greatly from leveraging previous work in development of OCRs during the Energy Needs for AAM at Scale Synthesis. Specifically, OCRs related to Battery Recyclability and Bio-designed Aircraft would be most relevant. 
In a separate vein, convening a cross-sector collaboration between the aviation, automotive, and wind turbine industries may enable breakthroughs and more concerted research on recyclability of CFRP. 

What questions would we like to explore further? As we look toward the future of aviation, we should be thinking about how to structure the aviation lifecycle in a way that mirrors the waste hierarchy and helps push the sector toward a resilient circular economy. Some initial elements to consider include:
How can we design our components such that we are preventing the use of critical materials like lithium and cobalt where possible?
How can we increase the longevity of these components? 
How might we scale and build toward flexible recycling processes capable of processing a wide-range of components?
How do we design and incentivize a circular aviation economy?
What other aircraft wastes have yet to be optimized? 
How might we design new aircraft that can still make use of old parts?
What would an aircraft that was 100% recyclable look like?
Key ongoing and related work 
Within NASA: University of Michigan using NASA’s Cyclone Global Navigation Satellite System (CYGNSS) to track ocean microplastics from space [4], Research on scrap recycling of retired civil aircraft [4]
Within other Government agencies: ReCell Center – DOE’s VTO recycling center
Within industry:  Redwood Materials, Aceleron, Li-Cycle, Battery Resourcers, Global Fiberglass Solutions, GE Renewable Energy, ZEBRA (Zero wastE Blade ReseArch) project, First Solar, ELG Carbon Fibre working with Boeing on composite recycling, North American Aerospace Industries (NAAI) (merged with Aircraft Interior Recycling Association) is focused on recycling 100% of aircraft and is building its first recycling facility in US to aid in that process [5], SUEZ group partnering with Qantas to reduce waste and manage waste streams, Boom supersonic working to incorporate recyclability into aircraft design [6], ELG Carbon Fibre and Aerocircular N.V. working together to establish closed-loop recycling scheme for end-of-life aircraft carbon-fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP) waste streams [7], Betteries [8]
Within academia: University of Sydney is developing an improved recycling process for CFRP [2], Princeton NuEnergy
Who should we involve in our exploration?  
Department of Energy, ReCell, IATA, National Renewable Energy Laboratory’s (NREL), International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), Aircraft Fleet Recycling Association

column1: Improving Connectivity and Resilience of Aviation Amid Climate Change
column5:
Background
Air transport helps drive the development and growth of our modern life. It provides the means to connect us to one another quickly, reliably, and safely. Air freights bring us flowers from Kenya, play a critical role in distributing vital medical supplies like the covid-19 vaccine, and expedite our supply chain. [3]
Aviation facilitates tourism, trade, and economic growth. Air transport is a major global employer, supporting 65.5 million jobs. The industry is responsible for roughly 2.7 trillion in global GDP. [1] [2] It improves the standard of living, alleviates poverty, connects remote communities, and enables a rapid response in the face of crisis. In 2021 alone, aviation proved to be a critical service in mitigating catastrophes and reconnecting the world.[3]
Aviation has proven to be a critical resource in enabling responsive action in the face of humanitarian crises and natural disasters. Aircraft are not only used to help respond to natural disasters like hurricanes but also to track and study them. [1] Most recently, air transport ensured safe and efficient evacuation out of Afghanistan and Ukraine. Air transport also facilitates the provision of humanitarian aid in the form of food and other commodities. [1] [4] [5]
As advancements in aviation make it more accessible, ubiquitous, and flexible – how can we use air transport to improve our quality of life? This topic area would focus on the power of connecting people and goods, enabling recreation and leisure time, and ensuring aviation remains able to respond to humanitarian crises and natural disasters.

When we consider the power of the future of aviation to connect and improve our lives, we may want to look at an “extreme user” as an example. Steven Rothstein purchased an unlimited, lifetime pass in 1987 – AAirpass, enabling him to fly anywhere in the world for the rest of his life. Over the course of 20 years, he accumulated some 30 million miles.
His son notes that traveling as frequently as they did made him feel “as at home in Copenhagen or Paris as I did in New York … I was a child of the world.” His father treated major hubs as if they were his offices, traveling to Amsterdam, Australia, India, and Japan with incredibly frequency. Airports, in turn, became his home. [1]
Steven used his AAirpass to indulge and experience, but also to build relationships. He gifted his accumulated miles to dozens and dozens of people he encountered along his travels, helping them to visit sick relatives, or to create meaningful experiences. In one such instance, he gifted miles to a group of priests so that they could fly to Italy to see the Vatican. [1] 
This story is a microcosm of how a more ubiquitous and accessible air transport system might change how we connect with the world and the people in it. The future airport may resemble your office or your home. Major international cities and yet-to-be developed ones may be visited with the frequency of regional domestic hubs. Strong connections and relationships may be made across state or country lines.
Compare that vision with the fact that a recent survey found that roughly 11% of Americans have not traveled outside of the state in which they were born. Imagine how impactful a more accessible and ubiquitous air transport system could be – broadening their horizons, fostering an understanding and appreciation of different cultures, and promoting global connections.[3]

Projected Impacts
It can be difficult to quantify the impact of some of the improvements air transport makes in our quality of life. We can say with certainty that air transport enables us to be more responsive in the fact of crises and increases our access to opportunities, experiences, business ventures, educations, medical services, and cultures that we may not otherwise have been able to enjoy. 
As we look to the future, aviation has the power to focus on continuing to improve other aspects of our quality of life, by making air transport more ubiquitous, accessible, and applicable to various challenges. Consider, for instance, the role aviation may play in reducing our commute times and decongesting our roadways – a factor which would enable many of us to experience more leisure time and reduce the stresses of mass transit.
Aviation has the potential to tackle many challenges within our modern world, including:
Urban design – helping us to shift to more walkable and connected cities
Education – bringing the world to life by increasing our access to it
Natural disasters and humanitarian crises – anticipating and responding to crises efficiently and effectively
Broadening our horizons – in a world that is increasingly global, how do we reconcile our own insular worldview? Aviation has the power to enable the public to experience more parts of the world in order to deepen their understanding of it. 

Rationale 
The responsiveness and connectivity that air transport provides will become increasingly critical in the face of climate crises, supply chain issues, ongoing and future pandemics, and our increasing desire for convenience, connection, and customization. 
Aviation is at the convergence of these trends and potential threats. How do we leverage the opportunity provided by advancements in aviation to improve our quality of life?

Recommended Next Steps & Critical Questions
What do we propose as a next step?  Synthesis Track Alpha to perform problem formulation and opportunity area discovery. This topic area is broad and unknown. There is a great deal of high-value exploration that can be undertaken. 

What questions would we like to explore further? What impact does air travel have on increasing cultural understanding and connecting us globally?
How can we leverage aviation to combat challenges that might negatively impact our quality of life?
How can we ensure that the benefits of aviation are accessible to the general public in order to ensure the greatest access of the benefits?
How can we envision a future where air travel enables us to experience and connect so that we can experience cities as locals rather than tourists?
What challenges might aviation best be equipped to tackle?

Who should we involve in that exploration?  
ICAO, ATAG, FAA, NOAA

column1: Reducing Harms and Increasing Benefits to Ecology
column5:
Many current conservation efforts in the aviation sector focus on reducing disturbances caused by noise and light pollution and potential wildlife strikes. These efforts are primarily focused on impacts to wildlife surrounding airports or airfields. 
To achieve the vision of Zero-Impact Aviation, we must:
Expand these efforts out to include the full aviation lifecycle. The impacts of mining and sourcing of materials on local ecology must be accounted for and built into sustainability efforts.   
Understand and address how the growth and expansion of aviation might impact local ecology through the increased transfer of invasive species, plant pathogens, and disease carrying insects. 

Background
This topic area reflects a shift in focus around impacts to local ecology to account for anticipated future growths in aviation and an expansion of thinking regarding the aviation lifecycle. 
First, as aviation becomes more ubiquitous and accessible through the advent of AAM, the disturbances to local ecology are likely to grow in kind. The noise and light pollution disturbances will no longer be isolated to airfields, but expanded out into urban, rural, and suburban environments. 
This growth in aviation will likely correlate with a growth in the worldwide aviation network (WAN). The growth of the WAN has been linked to increases in the rates of biological invasion, including invasive insects, plant pathogens, and disease carrying mosquitoes. 
Traffic and climate are shown to be constraints to this spread, but as international passenger numbers are projected to rise in conjunction with global temperatures, those constraints are increasingly uncertain. Passenger air travel is shown to be the predominate introduction vector in low-Human Development Index (HDI) regions. International air travel has been identified as a significant factor in the movement of economically damaging pest species, with 73% of recorded pest interceptions in the US occurring at airports. 
Second, many industries, including airlines, are beginning to expand their sustainability efforts to include the full lifecycle of their product or operation. Aviation is no different. Airlines like Cathay Pacific, Delta, and United are all thinking more broadly about their impacts. In the case of local ecology, a Zero-Impact Aviation effort should expand efforts to protect wildlife across the full aviation lifecycle, including mining and sourcing of materials. 
The green energy revolution is reliant on raw materials like cobalt and lithium, which are currently sourced through mining efforts. While a circular economy may be possible one day, efforts to scale these green industries up quickly are far outpacing advancements in recyclability. 
Zero-Impact Aviation should look beyond aviation operations when considering impacts to local ecology to include potential impacts of sourcing and mining these raw materials. 

Projected Impacts
Impacts to migratory patterns, habitats, and the potential increase of invasive species all pose a significant threat to ecosystem health and biodiversity. These impacts are particularly important in a changing climate, where healthy ecosystems provide the resilience necessary to adapt and continue functioning effectively and efficiently. 
Biodiversity is not just critical for healthy environments, it also supports human and social needs, including food and nutrition security, energy, development of medicines and pharmaceuticals and freshwater. 
The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) reports that "the current annual environmental, economic, and health-related costs of invasive species exceed those of all other natural disasters combined.” Alien species are the second leading cause of extinction in the US and cost approximately $120 billion annually. These invasions can threaten ecosystems, carry infectious disease, and reduce agricultural productivity, leading to food scarcity. 

Impact on Wildlife
There are a tremendous amount of unknowns regarding how aviation’s growth and expansion will impact local wildlife and biodiversity.  Decisions being made today in the name of sustainable aviation may threaten the sustainability of our healthy ecosystems tomorrow. More information is needed regarding the trade-offs of these decisions and the impact around the larger aviation lifecycle. Finally, aviation may prove useful in addressing many of these same challenges. Is it possible to leverage aviation as a conservation tool? 

Recommended Next Steps & Critical Questions
What do we propose as a next step?  Synthesis Track Alpha to perform problem formulation and opportunity area discovery. This topic area is broad and unknown. There is a great deal of high-value exploration that can be undertaken. 

What questions would we like to explore further? What impact would AAM have on transmission of invasive species?
How would growth in aviation impact biodiversity?
How can aviation be used as a conservation tool?
How can aviation mitigate its impacts on ecosystems across its lifecycle?

Who should we involve in that exploration?  
Department of Agriculture, USGS, CDC, US Environmental Protection Agency, US Fish and Wildlife Service, National Parks Service, Center for Biological Diversity, Major airlines, Mining companies, WHO, Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), International Seabed Authority

Ongoing and Related Work
Within NASA: Invasive Species Forecasting System (ISFS) combines NASA satellite data with field sample data to control invasive species, Acoustic Research Measurement (ARM) flights aimed at noise mitigation
Within other Government agencies: US Geological Survey using robotic DNA samplers to detect invasive freshwater species
Within industry:  Airlines are building biodiversity into their sustainability plans. Efforts to shift to deep sea mining and scale up recycling are aimed at combating impacts of terrestrial mining and materials sourcing. Advancements in mining industry like remote sensing can monitor impacts to ecosystem. Pressure to finalize regulations on deep-sea mining in 2-year timeframe could add an additional dimension. 
Within academia: University of Florida’s Vector-borne disease airline importation risk (VBD-Air) tool helps define the roles airports/airplanes play in transmitting diseases

Garry Qualls
Opportunity:Describe the problem NASA should be solving.  The description can also include notional desirability, key use cases, possible partnerships.NASA Aeronautics’ mission may predate NASA itself, but it continues to attack the aviation barriers of today and tomorrow, ensuring continued progress and growth.  A wide array of new entrants to aviation are working to transform aviation with new concepts, technologies and business models.  The initial challenges of how to certify their novel aircraft concepts have dominated efforts to date, but there are other, larger barriers to transforming aviation that NASA should be attacking.
At the recent Imagninaviation conference, the challenge of “industrializing” these new vehicles was highlighted as “the big risk” in this space. It’s a risk that exists where a vehicle’s design and manufacturing intersect with how it can be operated routinely, subject to the realities and economics of commercial flight services.  Will these new aircraft be able to function well enough, quickly enough, to earn a place in industry?  
My claim is that NASA and ARMD should have a significant role in reducing the time, cost, and effort to clear that barrier.  The USA should be the best place for aviation start-ups to innovate. How are you able to use automation to identify precursors to potential events and then automatically mitigate them, because right now we have done pretty good job of identifying post-flight events. In the current research that we have right now, we're able to identify and propose solutions to potential real-time events (or in-time events because some things don't have to be real time), but we really are trying to move towards automated mitigation as well, because the mitigation in the current environment is still left up to the human.

column1: Smart Structures and Systems Across Aviation and Civil Infrastructure
column5:
Research into smart structures and systems can provide critical insights: how might we shift to proactive maintenance of critical structures to reduce weight, increase uptime, and  
improve longevity? 

Advancements to smart structures and systems can improve safety and enable cost-effective decision making in maintenance and repair, both for aircraft and for civil infrastructure such as structurally deficient bridges. This is a case where aviation technology can learn from early adopters in civil infrastructure inspection and monitoring, and use NASA's engineering expertise to advance this technology area for mutual benefit.  

In this opportunity concept report (OCR), we describe prospective research avenues in smart structures and systems to improve aircraft monitoring and inspection, with mutual benefit to bridge monitoring. We’ve also included a narrative survey of the problem space in bridge monitoring and aircraft health management stemming from findings during a site visit, conversations with subject matter experts, and targeted literature review. The survey has emphasis on relevant technologies, economic impact, feasibility, regulatory environment, and alignment with NASA’s mission. 

Three solution vectors are outlined: (1) unmanned aircraft system (UAS) based automated inspection, (2) wireless distributed sensing, and (3) digital twin for reliability management. The UAS-based inspection and wireless distributed sensing complement each other’s strengths in providing safety improvements, with potential for disruptive economic impact by reducing maintenance costs and increasing aircraft longevity. Similar advantages apply to bridge and other infrastructure monitoring and inspection. An assessment of prospective research areas in the maturation path is provided, for example: system integration, demonstration cases, leveraging complementary inspection modalities, data format representation, and visualization needs.  

Core research and development areas emphasize aspects related to prototyping, system integration, demonstration for aeronautics impact, and digital twin development for cross-cutting use cases. The opportunity area includes significant potential for partnership across NASA groups, across programs, with other governmental agencies, with commercial entities, and with academic institutions. This area provides a unique opportunity for collaboration with the civil engineering research community, providing for cross-pollination between two seemingly disparate fields that are targeting similar underlying technological advancements. 

Investment in this technology area fits under “system-wide safety assurance” in NASA’s core strategic objective “Drive efficient and sustainable aviation” ?[1]?. NASA's "for the benefit of all" mandate makes this opportunity to serve two communities a good fit for Convergent Aeronautics Solutions (CAS).

column1: A Future-proofed Aviation Workforce - Leapfrogging Workforce Shortages and Building Rural Resiliency with AR-VR
column5:
Skilled worker shortages are forecast in all sectors of aviation, including pilots and maintenance/repair technicians. The use of Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality (AR/VR) devices and technologies are becoming standard equipment in many industries requiring trained workers to maintain and repair increasingly complex systems. Interviews with industry SMEs and our own online research indicate that pilot training is being modernized by the use of AR/VR in many of the larger aviation schools. This research also clearly identified a workforce and safety gap: certified UAS repair and maintenance technicians.  

The Connecting Rural Communities and Capabilities, (3C), sprint team explored how NASA might improve the lives and livelihoods of people in rural America. Workforce development, reskilling, and combatting “brain drain” as young people move from rural to urban centers were consistent challenges we heard in our research with rural stakeholders. Using AR/VR is an effective way to provide access to curriculum regardless of location and can bridge other access gaps for people with disabilities and other barriers such as distance or economic disadvantage. By leveraging trends identified in aviation workforce gaps as well as emerging technological capabilities, NASA is uniquely positioned to contribute to reducing this growing gap in workforce while simultaneously supporting economic resilience across America. 

The recent release of advanced AR/VR technologies (e.g. Apple’s Vision Pro, MS Hololens, and others) and development platforms indicates that hardware and software have reached a critical stabilizing moment: enduring capabilities with tailorable, modular, upgradable hardware and software.  

Promoting this area will also require collaboration with the FAA to develop and modernize the training requirements of UAS technicians as well as working with academia and industry to adopt this new technology on a broad basis and keep pace with innovation. Further collaboration with state and local economic development activities will help ensure equity across diverse populations and economic circumstances. 

Additionally, NASA’s own workforce could ultimately benefit from innovation in training. Dome simulators for pilots and astronauts cost $2-4K per hour compared to mere hundreds of dollars per hour with VR/AR according to Herbert Schilling who leads the Scientific Computing and Visualization Team and Graphics and Visualization (GVIS) Lab at Glenn Research Center. Further, faster training could solve huge turnover issues in rocket maintenance as they are —according to one NASA Stakeholder in the Space directorate—"hiring anyone they can find." Current NASA AR/VR efforts have been oriented towards data visualization. By developing and applying AR/VR technology to UAS maintenance, NASA solves one of its own issues in maintaining a reliable fleet of UAS to support its various missions. This OCR’s continuation could elevate and validate AR/VR for critical tasks and workforce development.
