column1: Icing Mitigation through Quantum Sensing
column5:
The primary focus of aircraft icing research has been on ice accretion on wings for its serious adverse consequences. When icing occurs on a wing, the change in airfoil shape results in a decrease in lift and an increase in drag, leading to potentially fatal accidents. Although the issue was recognized in the 1920s, the icing problem is still an area of ongoing research due to the complexity of the icing phenomena.
A much-improved understanding of how certain weather conditions produce different icing characteristics will lead to new mitigation methods and a better quantification of current methods. This can be done by better understanding of the molecular bonding energy produced by ice polytype combinations when interacting with different surface materials in various environments.
"Wicked-Wild" Idea:
This work is currently developing both models that more accurately describe the quantum signatures of H2O states (i.e. supercooled, ice, liquid, glass phase...) and chip-based detectors to evaluate these signatures. These sensors utilize ion defects in Silicon Carbide (SiC) as extremely sensitive atomic magnetic detectors. This effort leverages both the decades-long SiC development expertise and infrastructure at NASA Glenn and its growing capabilities in quantum metrology.

column1: Mars Airborne Explorer
column5:
Vehicle and mission design for Meso-scale scientific access to southern highlands of Mars.
Planetary researchers at ARC, APL, GRC, JPL, Universities, Academies of Science 	Aeronautics research centers – AFRC, ARC, GRC, LRC 	Martian Mission Planners - JPL Many of the problems presented by trying to develop a vehicle for the southern highlands of mars require pushing the boundaries on aeronautics design, rf systems, and concepts of operations. As such it is a balance between relying on tried-and-true methods and techniques and pushing the technological envelope to obtain better performance than was necessary for terrestrial applications.   •	Low density atmosphere results in low Reynolds number combined with high Mach Effects. •	CO2 atmospheric properties are different than air and are more difficult to predict. •	Air-launched after entry from space presents unique challenges. •	Unfolding a vehicle in flight on Mars has not been sufficiently investigated. •	Communicating critical events during flight over 250,000,000 km distance has not been solved. •	Change in weight due to gravity but fixed inertia complicates vehicle design. •	Time delay for data to Earth requires in-flight autonomous decisions on data selection. •	Data path to Earth is severely limited requiring data return over weeks and months.
Mission proposals for Discovery class will happen in 2026 and 2028. Project would need to develop and test critical components and conops prior to submission for these proposal windows.
When we need to show a Technical Review that the individual technologies are at a TRL of 6 or better for a mission proposal in the Discovery class.
Advances in wing loading such as bell span loading allow for stable aircraft designs that do not require a tail, or indeed any vertical surfaces and do not require complicated controllers. Avionics and Flight Controllers as well as highly autonomous systems in very small packages allow for a realistic flight package to be purchased COTS which improves testing and use terrestrially. Improvements in science instruments such as Helium 4 Optically Pumped Magnetometers and Quantum State Magnetometers allow for precise measurements of weak magnetic fields to be obtained in small instruments. Advances in RF system design and modeling to allow for conformal antennas and digital beamforming to be incorporated into aircraft skin.
The ability to air-launch a folded vehicle at high transonic speeds High lift configurations for low Reynolds number high speed vehicles Conformal antenna design and digital beam steering Landing on unprepared surfaces at reduced gravity and high speeds CFD, Wind Tunnels, Flight Testing, RF System Design, Aircraft Design, Propulsion Design, Composite Fabrication, high altitude balloons, sUAS aircraft, manned aircraft, high speed manned aircraft
A possible solution to the problem involves using a fixed wing aircraft that has very low wing loading, which is the same problem that a very high-altitude aircraft has. The vehicle will need to be low drag and low weight with a large wing area. Technological improvements for this kind of aircraft have spin off effects for the aviation industry as a whole, which is attempting to vastly reduce carbon footprint by 2050. The technologies envisioned for this problem can be directly applied to improve other efforts within ARMD, such as SFD or SUSAN. Improving data link rates while maintaining aerodynamic efficiency is of interest for commercial and defense aerospace.
NASA has aeronautics and space capabilities and knowledge that can help with design, wind tunnels, CFD servers, and airborne assets that can help with testing and iterations of design, and commercial partnerships that can be leveraged to make possible high altitude testing to improve TRL. NASA AFRC has institutional knowledge for tailless aircraft design utilizing bell spanloads, a more efficient and stable design technique to improve structural efficiency.
Development of a platform that can enter from space and traverse in a low-density environment has similar applications in earth science and defense observations. Earth science can benefit as the platform is well suited for in-situ measurements across air masses at very high altitudes in the 90,000-120,000’ range. This is a regime that cannot be easily studied by weather balloon. These measurements would have a large effect on improving weather modeling and forecasts. A vehicle that can enter from space and fly at these altitudes may be useful for defense applications as this is above surface to air missile range. Conformal antenna design and beam forming improve data throughput and security of airborne transmissions. Power generation incorporated into composite structures allows for new electrically powered or augmented aircraft design.
Martian exploration is currently limited to soft landings. This method requires either large fuel expenditures (expensive), use of a parachute (requires the higher density of lower elevations on Mars) or a combination of the two. To date, no vehicles have successfully landed at altitudes above the Martian datum, which effectively removes more than 50% of the surface from access. To leverage a fixed wing aircraft, the vehicle will need to fly comfortably at an altitude of 115,000’ MSL on earth. However, even with that testing, there are aspects that cannot be matched through testing on Earth and will have to be modeled. The first time the vehicle flies in the Martian atmosphere will be the first time it flies with all the conditions at the same time..

column1: Autonomous Navigation
column5:
Current navigation techniques are based on large infrastructure systems such a GPS, WAAS and RDF.  However, these systems do not exist on the Moon or Mars and on Earth are vulnerable to jamming due to conflict or natural events, such as solar storms.  The ongoing wars in Ukraine and the Middle East have demonstrated that regional GPS signals can be blocked (see the map provided below).  NASA’s recent Ingenuity helicopter demonstrated powered flight on Mars but could not leave the vicinity of its host, the Mars Perseverance Rover, because it had no regional navigation capability.  NASA’s Artemis program will be deploying rovers on the Moon in the next decade, without a planetary scale GPS network in place. What is needed is improved autonomous navigation capabilities which could allow aircraft and surface vehicles to navigate without any external infrastructure dependencies.
The stakeholders are planetary scientists and NASA mission planners such as the Ingenuity autonomous NASA helicopter that operated on Mars from 2021 to 2024 as part of the Mars 2020 mission.  In addition, commercial aviation and the US Air Force, which has recently been affected by Russian GPS spoofing in Europe and the Middle East. The development of new navigation systems can endanger human life.  Such a system will need to be developed in coordination with the FAA and DOT.
For terrestrial civilian and military applications, the problem is current.  GPS is currently being jammed in the war zones of Ukraine and the Middle East. For NASA the problem will become current in the late 2020s when the Mars Sample Return mission will deploy multiple helicopters to the surface of Mars.  NASA will also need these capabilities in the early 2030s when the Artemis program will start sending astronauts and rovers to the moon. 
It already is for terrestrial applications and will in the late 2020s for NASA.
Continue conflict in the Middle East and Europe and NASA’s plans to explore the Moon and Mars.
Improved regional autonomous navigation systems.
Blocking of GPS directly affects aviation safety.
Yes, there are extensive capabilities at many NASA Centers. For example, the Ames Flight Dynamics team and synthetic biology and bioengineering groups; the National Space-Based Positioning; Navigation and Timing Executive Committee (EXCOM); NASA’s Space Communications and Navigation (SCaN) Program; the Global Differential GPS (GDGPS); Tracking and Data Relay Satellite (TDRS); and JSC Guidance, Navigation & Control Subsystems .
Safer air travel and safer planetary exploration.
There are many organizations and companies interested in working in this space.  NASA should establish a consortium to bring these entities together to ensure coordination and that solutions meet NASA, FAA and DOT standards while protecting individual intellectual property rights.

column1: Collaborative Hydrogen Testing Area
column5:
There is a large and increasing need for hydrogen test capabilities for the development of components, subsystems, and systems for aircraft and other transportation systems. Industry is showing a desire to develop systems for clean energy solutions, but testing with hydrogen, and especially liquid hydrogen is challenging and costly. Furthermore, there is a need to explore the trade-space around operational aircraft refueling.  There may be synergistic ways to combine the two problems.
NASA, DOE, FAA, DOT, US Industry around the country that are developing or qualifying liquid hydrogen technologies. Large portions of government involvement are driven to help enable US Industry to achieve decarbonization goals.Costs of implementations / changes to infrastructure Hydrogen safety / public perception around hydrogen safety Achieving consensus among stakeholders on a viable and integrated development approach.
Years to 10s of years
Within the next 5 years if there are insufficient testing facilities developed, hydrogen will likely self-select out as a solution.
Currently, the development of hydrogen fueled transportation systems, both for DOT and DOE as ground transportation (medium to heavy duty trucks, trains) are driving development in the hydrogen transportation space.  The capabilities necessary for hydrogen-fueled aircraft will be different largely because of increased sensitivity to weight. 
The ability to procure, store, distribute (within a facility/site), and dispose of/recover liquid hydrogen, as well as control temperature and pressure, adapt to various test article sizes and configurations, and safely perform LH2 testing are needed for the energy and transportation infrastructure.
The components that need testing would be directly applicable to aircraft and also go within the airport infrastructure for handling cryogenic fuel and loading it onto aircraft.
Yes, NASA has extensive expertise in cryogenic system testing as well as multiple test facilities and capabilities that could be leveraged that are currently not being fully utilized. Additional investments could enable enhanced capabilities in existing facilities and the development of new capabilities better suited to a specific application. These resources are mainly at GRC, WSTF, and to a lesser extent at a few other centers. Potential partners include the DOE, FAA, Hydrogen Distribution Companies (Linde, Air Liquide, etc)
Technologies get stuck in the valley of death and can’t quickly mature for implementation or are matured/implemented in an unsafe manner that puts undue and uninformed members of the public at risk.
Implementation of test facilities are expensive due to the complexities of handling liquid hydrogen and safety requirements. Additionally, the general level of experience handling liquid hydrogen within US Industry is low. This is a problem across multiple industries that is being experienced by multiple government agencies as the hydrogen infrastructure and research capital in the US grows.  Use of NASA facilities and expertise to supplement US Industry allows the nation to claim full use of the investments that it has made through NASA over the past 60+ years.
